item.question: You want to do a routine checkup on your system to see if anyone is trying to hack your way into the system. Which of the following commandlines would you use to check how many times remote users have opened a secure shell to the system?
item.hint: As authentication information is considered sensitive, most Linux distributions will log authentication information in a separate log file. This allows the system to restrict access to a specific user or group.

item.question: You need to add user guru0 to the group students. Which of the following commands will be BEST to perform this task?
item.hint: These kind of questions are great for answering other questions, as it clearly tells you which command you can use to modify a user account. To answer this question correctly you must know which option will add the group to the user's additional groups. Although you can make the user a member of the group by changing its primary group. The question mentions adding the user to the group and not replacing acurrent group membership. So your safest bet would be to add the group to the user's additional groups.

item.question: Which section in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/X11/xorg.conf</font> allows you to specify the video resolutions for specific colour depths?
item.hint: A single Xorg server can manage multiple screens on multiple monitors. For each screen you can specify the video resolution and colour depth.

item.question:
You downloaded a script and notice that the first line starts with #!.
What is the purpose of this line?
item.choice: The command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> will replace the script
The shell will execute the command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> to interpret the script.
The <font face="monospace">#!</font> sign tells the shell where to start executing the script
The line will be ignored as it starts with <font face="monospace">#</font>
item.correct_answer: The shell will execute the command after the <font face="monospace">#!</font> to interpret the script.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You need to convert a textfile using the WINDOWS-1253 character encoding
to UTF-8. Which of the following commands allows you to do this?

Consider the following commandline:
What does the above commandline do?
item.choice: Syntax error as an opening bracket must be preceeded by an <font face="monospace">if</font>-keyword.
Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
Check if <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> has execution permissions and if so will not execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
Simultaneously run two instances of <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
item.correct_answer: Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
If you want to execute a script called findguru and want to disable the variable GURU only for the current
execution of the script, which of the following commandlines is correct?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: A possible problem with running scripts is that a mistake can lead to an explosure of new processes. This may result in the system becoming unresponsive. How can you minimize the impact of these mistakes?
item.choice: Include the line <font face="monospace">ulimit -u 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/profile</font>.
Include the line <font face="monospace">* hard nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
Include the line <font face="monospace">* soft nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
Find the user who wrote the script and have a good talk about programming practices
item.correct_answer: Include the line <font face="monospace">* hard nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
item.hint: When a process reaches its soft limit it will be denied any more of the limited resource. However, a user is allowed to increase the soft limit up to the hard limit. You can also think of it as the soft limit being a default and the hard limit being the absolute maximum.

item.question: You just migrated your DNS server to a new machine and now need to update the clients to use the new DNS server. Which file do you need to change?
item.hint: The C library many programs use contains routines that provide access to DNS. This set of routines is called the resolver.

item.question:
Consider the following exhibit
What does the number 20738 represent?
item.choice: the process ID of the last command executed in the background
the process ID of the echo command
the process ID of the last command executed in the foreground
the process ID of the current shell
item.correct_answer: the process ID of the current shell

item.question: You want to convert the text-file <font face="monospace">guru.txt</font> to postscript to have it printed out later on. Which of the following commandlines would you use to accomplish this?

item.question: What is the correct order in which the BASH shell will search for a command?
item.hint: When you provide a pathname, i.e. the commandname contains a forward slash, you tell the shell exactly where to find the command. Therefore it does not have to search for it in this case. When you only provide the commandname (i.e. without a forward slash) the shell will search for a command with the given name. This can be either a builtin (shell function) or an executable on a filesystem.

item.question:
In the passwd file, you changed /bin/bash to
/bin/false for user bob. What best describes the effect on bob's
account?
item.choice: When bob logs in on a terminal screen it will run the command <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font>
Bob will be asked to provide a new shell to use
item.correct_answer: When bob logs in on a terminal screen it will run the command <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font>

item.question: Which of the following lines do you usually find at the beginning of a shell script?
item.hint: When you execute a shell script as a normal command the first line is used by the kernel to determine which interpreter must be started to actually read and execute the script. Therefore, the first line should point to the shell command. Now you only need to know if the magic key is just a hash or a hash bang...

item.question: Which of the following configuration files is used to configure access through XDMCP for remote X11 clients?
item.hint: In this case the hint is in the question ;)............ access.\nThe file xdm.conf is the main configuration file and usually specifies other files to hold specific configuration information. The Xsession is used by the program Xsession that will run as the user's session and setup the user's X environment. The file Xresources usually contains parameters for X widgets, such as color, size, etc.

item.question: Which of the following is true for Open Source?
item.choice: The source code is freely available
You can do whatever you want with the source code and executables
item.correct_answer: The source code is freely available
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: How would you temporarily disable a user's login account?
item.choice: By changing the user's password and changing it back when the account needs to be enabled again.
By setting the user's shell to <font face="monospace">/usr/sbin/nologin</font> and changing it back to the default shell when the account needs to be enabled again.
Removing the user's entry in <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>.
Deleting the user account and recreate it afterwards.
item.correct_answer: By changing the user's password and changing it back when the account needs to be enabled again.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want to copy all files in the current directory to the directory <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>. Which of the following scripts will copy all regular files without generating any file-permission errors knowing that you have write permissions for <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>?
item.hint: We went a little overboard on this question and provided many choices with subtle differences. Read all choices very carefully and pay good attention to the if-statements.

item.question: Which of the following would be best to use to make programs show time messages in the dutch locale?
item.hint: Although in theory multiple choices are correct the question asks about the best choice. Therefore, you should pick the one that most specifically answers the question and will always work (i.e. not dependent on a specific environment).

item.question:
Your company policy does not allow anything but ssh as a remote login service.
During your monthly security audit you discover that one of your machines provides remote login services
on port 23. What would you do?
item.choice: Deactivate it, you dont need a SMTP server there.
Deactivate it, you should not use <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.
Nothing, this is ok as <font face="monospace">ssh</font> is a safe login service.
Setup a firewall on the machine to block traffic to port 23.
item.correct_answer: Deactivate it, you should not use <font face="monospace">telnet</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You notice that a lot of users complain that reading manpages is very inconvenient and ask you if you can change the pager to use the command <font face="monospace">less</font> instead of <font face="monospace">more</font>. Which of the following files would you edit to make this change.
item.hint: The default pager can be set through the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable. Therefore, you will need to find a way to set the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable each time a user logs in and starts a shell. Also note that the skel directory is only effective for new users. The question is about changing the pager for current users as well.
